thread.title: Ducks receiver Darren Carrington cited for alcohol violation
thread.title_full: Ducks receiver Darren Carrington cited for alcohol violation | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Greif | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Ducks receiver Darren Carrington cited for alcohol violation
text:
Early in the morning of Sept. 26, hours before his Oregon Ducks teammates lost their Pac-12 Conference opener to Utah, ineligible receiver Darren Carrington was cited by Eugene police for an open container violation, police said.
According to Eugene police spokeswoman Melinda McLaughlin, officers on "party patrol" found Carrington, 20, in an alley near Eugene's East 14th Avenue and Patterson Street at 2:34 a.m., holding a cup that appeared to contain alcohol. The officers confirmed it was alcohol, and issued a citation in lieu of custody, McLaughlin said.
Several other people in the alley were being cited at the same time, McLaughlin said, and the officers chose not to write additional citations — such as minor in possession — out of their discretion to save time. The "party patrol" had fewer officers available than normal, she said, as earlier in the evening a Lane County Sheriff's deputy had been shot in nearby Cottage Grove.
A team spokesman said any punishment will remain internal but didn't indicate whether the citation would affect Carrington's expected return to the field next week against Washington State.
The citation, which comes with an appearance in Eugene's Municipal Court on Oct. 16, comes nine months after Carrington failed an NCAA-run drug test that forced him to miss the College Football Playoff national championship game against Ohio State, as well as the first five games of this season.
Oregon had appealed the length of the punishment to the NCAA, but did not receive any relief.
Carrington was not with the team at the time of the citation because of that ineligibility. Oregon (2-2, 0-1 Pac-12) plays Saturday at Colorado (3-1) in what had been expected to be the final game Carrington must sit out.
His breakout game of the 2014 season came in the playoff semifinal at the Rose Bowl against Florida State, in which he caught seven passes for 165 yards and two touchdowns.
His return to the lineup has become more important this week with a report that the team's leading receiver in 2014, Byron Marshall, could miss the season due to a leg injury.
Head coach Mark Helfrich classified Marshall's status as "week-to-week" on Thursday.
-- Andrew Greif
